text:
Hey Y'all! Just wanted to share a case study I wrote for Databox. It's my first one in an ongoing relationship and they just posted it! :slightly_smiling_face:
<https://databox.com/databox-case-study-arxus>

attachments.title: How Arxus Makes Performance Data More Accessible & Now Hits 85% of Its Goals | Databox Blog
attachments.text: With Databox, Arxus accesses and streamlines their data quickly and with ease, while saving time and spotting trends 80% faster.
attachments.fallback: Databox: How Arxus Makes Performance Data More Accessible & Now Hits 85% of Its Goals | Databox Blog

elements.text: Hey Y'all! Just wanted to share a case study I wrote for Databox. It's my first one in an ongoing relationship and they just posted it!

text: Awesome post, Allison! Loved how you ended it with Databox's standout feature. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Awesome post, Allison! Loved how you ended it with Databox's standout feature.

text:
This is great. I love Shopify as a platform. It's super clean and simple.

But, when it comes to SEO, WordPress/WooCommerce is still king for most agencies. The flexibility is just unbeaten.

I'm sure you know working at agency we have routines / processes for every SEO issue, and usually the deeper you can dive the more results you can bring, especially if competition is tight and you want to get an edge.

I wish Shopify was as flexible as WP, I really love the platform, but it has a lot of limits compared to WordPress or a custom-built site. I haven't checked in a while, so, what I would want to see is how far it's gotten now.

Something like:
SEO: WooCommerce vs Shopify - SEO processes for each platform compared in Q4 2020

If we wanted to start working on Shopify stores too, we'd need to build / test / iterate processes for each SEO issue on Shopify. We'd need to test and choose apps, figure out workarounds (I'm guessing)...

Basically, we'd need to compare it to how we would get something done on WordPress, and then see what % or what kind of flexibility we're losing if we keep a site on Shopify.

The closer that gets to 0%, the more SEO agencies will start using Shopify (exponentially)

text: If I wasn't working full-time++ I'd build similar stores on WooCommerce and Shopify, compete against myself for some random product keywords and see which platform has the edge — and by how far :man-shrugging:
